body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

We have some internal code which crashes with a segmentation fault. There was no unsafe code anywhere near the calling site, so this was unexpected. When analyzed it turned out to be an invalid stack access in the generated code. Unfortunately we could not reduce this to a compact reproducer. So far as we know there's only one instance of this bug affecting generated code in our codebase, but we haven't yet eliminated the possibility of a non-faulting manifestation.  Using new-pass-manager eliminates the problem in this case.

It turned out to be a bug with llvm's alias analysis. Upstream proposed fix and discsussion: https://reviews.llvm.org/D91576

I'm filing this mostly as a heads up to wg-llvm to make sure that once the fix has landed in llvm it gets picked up in the next Rust release.

cc @mjhostet, @dtolnay 

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.47.0-dev
LLVM Version: 9.0
```
We are building this against an in-house version of llvm 9.0 with some local modifications. It's not clear why this problem started manifesting in 1.47.0.
